data.output: It was that time of year when there was a lot of gloom around. This was because it was time for the payment of council tax. A new rule meant that even if you did not have a house if you exist then you pay.

data.output: Wendy was extremely distressed. She had returned home from work to a pile of letters, and she looked with some dismay at the first letter with a red banding. Gloom descended across her face when she realised that she owed a payment to a holiday company; she had forgotten to pay her deposit. Wendy wondered why debt collection companies had to exist, so she decided to pack up her belongings and instead went backpacking.

data.output: Sarah was suffering with a case of the blues lately, it was all doom and gloom in her mind and feeling like she was simply existing rather than living.  Sarah felt like her adult days were poor, one payment after the other coming out of her hard earned money.  She told everyone around her she was all work and no play in order to simply exist in the world, and it was not the life she wanted.

data.output: I went for a walk into the forbidden forest today, it was always described with gloom. I knew that there was a reason we took the long path home every evening from work. I venture forward into the dark, I see a dark coin goblin shaking his bag menacingly, I thought these didn't exist, I managed to make it home but not without payment, the goblin took all my coffers for the day and now I am left with nothing.

data.output: As they looked out of the small wooden window in their apartment, Jess and Nat were lamenting their current situation. As students with no jobs, they had little money and the payment for this month's rent was nearly due. The rainy day outside seemed to exist only to exacerbate those negative feelings and make it increasingly hard to pull oneself out of perpetual gloom.  Jess stood up suddenly, turning to Nat she smiled. "I have an idea!!" she said.

data.output: Marcus peered through the gloom. "Why were there no lights?" he wondered, as he cupped his hands against the window to try and see inside the house. Perhaps the family had failed to make their payment, but without power in the midst of this winter, the family would suffer fatally. There was no sign of life inside, and Marcus prayed silently they had moved on before the freeze and weren't to be found inside. Once, there were charities to help and places to go, but in these no longer exist: too many require help, and no one has any left to give.
data.summary: gloom surrounding an unpaid payment with no existing aid

data.output: Under the gloom of this overgrown rainforest there was a world one would never imagine to exist. Banks carved from caverns filled with fairies queuing to take out loans. A doctor's office in the hollow of an elm tree, specifically for the health problems of orphaned munchkins. Atop this same tree, way up in the canopy, was the factory run by the local snarks -- who controlled the printing of all currency used to make any payment you could think of -- only from youngest elm leaves.

data.output: 'I no longer wish to exist' said the despondent boy sat underneath the tree - it seemed as though his gloom had finally overcome him entirely. data.output: The current political climate left Rachel feeling a sense of gloom.
